image.altText: Nurse in home

props.synopsis: Union representatives say it took four nurses getting assaulted and a prohibition order before Canberra Health Services listened to their calls for safety. Now they say safety is worse than before.

title.children: 'It could result in death': Nurses assaulted during in-home visits

image.altText: OnlyFans logos displayed on a laptop and a phone screens.

props.synopsis: The ACT Magistrates Court finds a woman who refused to take down intimate images of herself and a former partner on her OnlyFans page, after he withdrew consent, acted out of a desire for retribution.

title.children: Woman spared jail for posting intimate images with ex-partner online

props.synopsis: The National Library is asking for contributions to its election ephemera collection which it's been building since federation, collecting posters of former Prime Minister John Howard, flyers for Kevin ’07 and even how to vote cards from the early 1900s.

title.children: Election pamphlets may be 'annoying' but they tell a story of Australia

image.altText: A woman in glasses holds her baby who wears a grey wiggles jumpsuit.

props.synopsis: The mother-of-two is among a growing number of people seeking out food relief for the first time, which includes families and people with stable jobs and mortgages.

title.children: Skylee turned to free food pantries to feed her family and she's far from alone

image.altText: A middle-aged, fair-haired woman in a brightly-coloured blazer.

props.synopsis: Katy Gallagher says her seniority as finance minister helps her advocate for Canberra. She admits independent Senator David Pocock is popular, but says her party has more muscle.

title.children: Gallagher seeks fourth Senate win but concedes Pocock's popularity

image.altText: Senate House of Reps generic composite

props.synopsis: ACT residents will be voting for both their House of Representatives member and their two Senate representatives in the federal election on Saturday May 3.

title.children: Voting in the ACT this federal election? Here's what you should know

image.altText: A woman kneels by a lake painting a canvas in a paint-splattered button down shirt.

props.synopsis: With a canvas strapped to her back atop her bike, artist Sophie Baker cuts an unusual figure in the Canberra bush — now artists like her are ditching the studio to embrace painting in the open air as part of a new festival.

title.children: 'Into the bush': Artists ditch the studio to embrace open air painting

image.altText: Raw lamb chops.

props.synopsis: China grants access to more Australian lamb and mutton as it looks for other markets during the trade war with US President Donald Trump.

title.children: More Aussie sheep meat will be sent to China as trade wars continue

image.altText: An older man stands in front of rows of wine in a store.

props.synopsis: Phillip Randel Maurice Parry, 18, who is charged with murder over the death of Darwin supermarket owner Linford Feick, has faced court for the first time since the fatal stabbing.

title.children: Teen faces court charged with murder of Darwin supermarket owner

image.altText: Woman stands in courtroom, woman in road in top left-hand corner

props.synopsis: The opening day of the inquest has been told there was evidence of "rudimentary planning" and in the years prior Joel Cauchi had purchased knives which were used on the day of the attack that killed six people.

title.children: Bondi Junction stabber's search history revealed 'preoccupation with death'

image.altText: A woman with a 7 News microphone in front of her face.

props.synopsis: The triple-murder trial of Erin Patterson over an allegedly poisonous mushroom meal starts on Tuesday in the regional Victorian town of Morwell.

title.children: The key details ahead of Erin Patterson's triple-murder trial

image.altText: Adonis Quita (middle) who witnessed the event, sings during a worship service.

props.synopsis: Witnesses at the scene of a deadly car ramming in Vancouver detail the incident, as the death toll continues to climb.

title.children: Witnesses recount deadly Vancouver car ramming attack

image.altText: Donna Nelson graphic

props.synopsis: Grandmother Donna Nelson sits alone in a Japanese jail for 23 hours a day, far from the life she planned with her online boyfriend of two years. The court accepted the 59-year-old was love scammed, but sentenced her anyway.

title.children: Donna's trip of a lifetime landed her in jail in Japan

image.altText: Two Indigenous men stand on a smoky stage, one playing a didgeridoo and the other dressed in traditional dress

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton suggests Anzac Day dawn services should not involve Welcome to Country ceremonies and says most veterans do not support having them at the events.

title.children: Dutton suggests Anzac Day services should not involve Welcomes to Country

image.altText: A photo of China's crewed submersible, the Fendhouze, held aloft above the water before going in.

props.synopsis: China's new cable-cutter has been making headlines, but how much of a threat is it really?

title.children: What China's new cable-cutter signals for Australia

image.altText: Peter Dutton, wearing a suit and tie, opens his mouth to speak, standing outdoors with trees behind him.

props.synopsis: A Four Corners investigation finds Opposition Leader Peter Dutton failed to disclose his interest in a family trust for two years.

title.children: Business records reveal new details of Dutton family's childcare millions

image.altText: Roy Conry stands behind a desk with equipment on it

props.synopsis: Toolmaking and engineering pattern-making was once a thriving industry and is still a critical part of the supply chain in Australia, but the sector has shrunk, leaving the remaining tradies struggling to keep up with demand.

title.children: The dying trade critical to keeping Australian manufacturing alive

image.altText: A old photo of Kim Kardashian wearing a flashly large engagement ring

props.synopsis: When Kim Kardashian was tied up, held at gunpoint and robbed of more than $US10 million in jewellery, it was the biggest robbery of an individual in France for decades. Almost 10 years later, the case is going to trial.

title.children: Kim Kardashian's social media the perfect blueprint for Paris robbers

image.altText: Australian bank notes laid on white background

props.synopsis: The ASX closed 0.4 per cent higher. Ratings agency S&P warned election promises may pressure Australia's credit rating. See how the day unfolded on our live blog.

title.children: ASX closes higher, S&P warns Australia's triple-A credit rating at risk — as it happened

image.altText: A woman in yellow jumper holding shopping bag faces a supermarket shelf full of colourful wrapped foods.

props.synopsis: Both Labor and the Coalition have announced tax concessions ahead of polling day on May 3. Here's how much you could potentially save under Labor or the Coalition.

title.children: Major parties have pledged tax relief. Calculate what it means for you

image.altText: Peter Dutton and Anthony Albanese smiling on rainbow background.

props.synopsis: While there is broad agreement that Peter Dutton has a narrower path to victory than Anthony Albanese, campaigners are bracing for the unexpected.

title.children: Here's the state of play in dozens of seats that could decide the election

image.altText: An Asian man and a South Asian woman

props.synopsis: 'Cross-cultural kids' Kevin Han and Muna Hamid were both born in Australia to migrant families but they had very different childhoods. Now as adults, they reflect on their identity-shaping experiences and share the struggles and strengths of their upbringings.

title.children: 'I didn't know any white people': Growing up in Australia as a cross-cultural kid

image.altText: A black and white dairy cow looks up from its trough of feed

props.synopsis: The South Australian government provides $3 million in support for dairy farmers affected by the collapse of Beston Global Food.

title.children: $3m lifeline for dairy farmers out of pocket as processor liquidated

image.altText: A photo collage shows three voters from the seat of Deakin.

props.synopsis: Voters in Australia's most marginal seat tell us they're worried no-one is equipped to deliver the future they want.

title.children: These 19 people know their vote carries a lot of weight this election

image.altText: Green PM Jens-Frederik Nielsen and Danish PM Mette Frederiksen smile

props.synopsis: Greenland's new prime minister visits Denmark following months of tension over the US president's repeated declarations that the territory should become part of the United States.

title.children: Greenland strengthens ties with Denmark amid Trump's interest in controlling territory

props.synopsis: Last year, more than one million Australians travelled to the United States. But if you’re planning to visit, be aware that under Trump things have changed. Border checks have intensified with some travellers unexpectedly being denied entry, detained and deported.

title.children: The risks of travelling to Trump’s America

image.altText: Mother charged infant

props.synopsis: The woman was arrested in January and charged with administering poison with intent to harm, making child exploitation material and fraud.

title.children: Case against TikTok influencer accused of child torture 'large and complex'

image.altText: drone shot of a hospital sitting among leafy suburban streets

props.synopsis: I've seen the future of an important part of Australia's healthcare system — a private hospital owned by a health insurance company.

title.children: A private hospital opens in Melbourne with no out-of-pocket costs

image.altText: Headshot of Aunty Joy wearing classes and a possum fur coat.

props.synopsis: Aunty Joy Murphy Wandin says she does not know if she could work with Melbourne Storm again after the NRL club cancelled her Welcome to Country ceremony on Anzac Day.

title.children: Aboriginal elder told Welcome to Country 'inappropriate' on Anzac Day

image.altText: A boys sits on red blanket with a white bandage over his head

props.synopsis: Seven-year-old Ali Faraj Faraj, covered in blood and dust, could be seen crying amongst the rubble of a home in Gaza City. His father and five sisters were killed in the strike on Thursday.

title.children: A blast threw this 7yo on his neighbour's roof — his father's body lay feet away

image.altText: close up of woman's hands at computer with coffee mug

props.synopsis: It is helpful to be as financially prepared as possible before leaving a relationship — especially if you are a woman, experts say.

title.children: Being financially prepared before ending a relationship

image.altText: A hand holding a phone with a computer in the background

props.synopsis: As artificial intelligence becomes more prolific in modern society, scammers are using the tool to produce highly convincing scams that leave even the experts second-guessing.

title.children: The ABC fact-checked an AI scam. Here's what we found

image.altText: A photo of Samuel Hockey.

props.synopsis: A new nasal spray that uses a form of ketamine to treat stubborn depression will be added to the PBS, making treatment cheaper for thousands of Australians.

title.children: Ketamine-based nasal spray 'just the beginning' for depression patients

image.altText: An illustration of climate change for the Australian Federal Election 2025.

props.synopsis: As the election campaign draws to a close, it's safe to say both major parties have been quiet on climate change. While Labor policies have made some progress to decarbonise, the Coalition threatens to scrap or weaken them.

title.children: Where do the major parties stand on climate? Turns out they’re worlds apart

image.altText: Sara Shams stands in front of garden

props.synopsis: As someone who lives at the intersection of disability, womanhood, and cultural diversity, I experience the weight of language every day.

title.children: Using positive language around my disability shows you care
